column2: _The Wild Swans_
column3: underscore The Wild Swans underscore

column2: FAR away in the land to which the swallows fly when it is winter, dwelt a king who had eleven sons, and one daughter named Eliza.
column3: FAR away in the land to which the swallows fly when it is winter, dwelt a king who had eleven sons, and one daughter named Eliza.

column2: The eleven brothers were princes, and each went to school with a star on his breast and a sword by his side.
column3: The eleven brothers were princes, and each went to school with a star on his breast and a sword by his side.

column2: They wrote with diamond pencils on gold slates, and learned their lessons so quickly and read so easily that everyone might know they were princes.
column3: They wrote with diamond pencils on gold slates, and learned their lessons so quickly and read so easily that everyone might know they were princes.

column2: Their sister Eliza sat on a little stool of plate glass, and had a book full of pictures which had cost as much as half a kingdom.
column3: Their sister Eliza sat on a little stool of plate glass, and had a book full of pictures which had cost as much as half a kingdom.

column2: Oh, these children were indeed happy, but they were not to remain so always.
column3: Oh, these children were indeed happy, but they were not to remain so always.

column2: Their father, who was King of the country, married a very wicked Queen who did not love the poor children at all. They knew this from the very first day after the wedding.
column3: Their father, who was King of the country, married a very wicked Queen who did not love the poor children at all. They knew this from the very first day after the wedding.

column2: In the palace there were great festivities, and the children played at receiving company; but instead of having, as usual, all the cakes and apples that were left, she gave them some sand in a teacup and told them to pretend it was cake.
column3: In the palace there were great festivities, and the children played at receiving company; but instead of having, as usual, all the cakes and apples that were left, she gave them some sand in a teacup and told them to pretend it was cake.

column2: The week after she sent little Eliza into the country to a peasant and his wife, and then she told the King so many untrue things about the young princes that he gave himself no more trouble respecting them.
column3: The week after she sent little Eliza into the country to a peasant and his wife, and then she told the King so many untrue things about the young princes that he gave himself no more trouble respecting them.

column2: Go out into the world and get your own living, said the Queen.
column3: Go out into the world and get your own living, said the Queen.

column2: Fly like great birds who have no voice. But she could not make them ugly as she wished, for they were turned into eleven beautiful wild swans.
column3: Fly like great birds who have no voice. But she could not make them ugly as she wished, for they were turned into eleven beautiful wild swans.

column2: Then, with a strange cry, they flew through the windows of the palace, over the park, to the forest beyond.
column3: Then, with a strange cry, they flew through the windows of the palace, over the park, to the forest beyond.

column2: It was yet early morning when they passed the peasant's cottage, where their sister Eliza lay asleep in her room.
column3: It was yet early morning when they passed the peasant's cottage, where their sister Eliza lay asleep in her room.

column2: They hovered over the roof, twisted their long necks, and flapped their wings; but no one heard them or saw them, so they were at last obliged to fly away, high up in the clouds; and over the wide world they flew till they came to a thick, dark wood, which stretched far away to the seashore.
column3: They hovered over the roof, twisted their long necks, and flapped their wings; but no one heard them or saw them, so they were at last obliged to fly away, high up in the clouds; and over the wide world they flew till they came to a thick, dark wood, which stretched far away to the seashore.

column2: Poor little Eliza was alone in her room playing with a green leaf, for she had no other playthings, and she pierced a hole through the leaf and looked through it at the sun, and it was as if she saw her brothers' clear eyes, and when the warm sun shone on her cheeks she thought of all the kisses they had given her.
column3: Poor little Eliza was alone in her room playing with a green leaf, for she had no other playthings, and she pierced a hole through the leaf and looked through it at the sun, and it was as if she saw her brothers' clear eyes, and when the warm sun shone on her cheeks she thought of all the kisses they had given her.

column2: One day passed just like another; sometimes the winds rustled through the leaves of the rosebush, and would whisper to the roses, "Who can be more beautiful than you?" But the roses would shake their heads and say, "Eliza is." And when the old woman sat at the cottage door on Sunday and read her hymn book, the wind would flutter the leaves and say to the book, "Who can be more pious than you?" and then the hymn book would answer, "Eliza." And the roses and the hymn book told the real truth.
column3: One day passed just like another; sometimes the winds rustled through the leaves of the rosebush, and would whisper to the roses, "Who can be more beautiful than you?" But the roses would shake their heads and say, "Eliza is." And when the old woman sat at the cottage door on Sunday and read her hymn book, the wind would flutter the leaves and say to the book, "Who can be more pious than you?" and then the hymn book would answer, "Eliza." And the roses and the hymn book told the real truth.

column2: At fifteen she returned home, but when the Queen saw how beautiful she was, she became full of spite and hatred toward her.
column3: At fifteen she returned home, but when the Queen saw how beautiful she was, she became full of spite and hatred toward her.

column2: Willingly would she have turned her into a swan, like her brothers, but she did not dare to do so yet, because the King wished to see his daughter.
column3: Willingly would she have turned her into a swan, like her brothers, but she did not dare to do so yet, because the King wished to see his daughter.

column2: Early one morning the Queen went into the bathroom; it was built of marble, and had soft cushions trimmed with the most beautiful tapestry.
column3: Early one morning the Queen went into the bathroom; it was built of marble, and had soft cushions trimmed with the most beautiful tapestry.

column2: She took three toads with her and kissed them, and said to one: "When Eliza comes to the bath, seat yourself upon her head, that she may become as stupid as you are." Then she said to another: "Place yourself on her forehead, that she may become as ugly as you are, and that her father may not know her." "Rest on her heart," she whispered to the third, "then she will have evil inclinations, and suffer in consequence." So she put the toads into clear water, and they turned green immediately.
column3: She took three toads with her and kissed them, and said to one: "When Eliza comes to the bath, seat yourself upon her head, that she may become as stupid as you are." Then she said to another: "Place yourself on her forehead, that she may become as ugly as you are, and that her father may not know her." "Rest on her heart," she whispered to the third, "then she will have evil inclinations, and suffer in consequence." So she put the toads into clear water, and they turned green immediately.

column2: She next called Eliza and helped her to undress and get into the bath.
column3: She next called Eliza and helped her to undress and get into the bath.

column2: As Eliza dipped her head under the water one of the toads sat on her hair, a second on her forehead, and a third on her breast, but she did not seem to notice them, and when she rose out of the water there were three red poppies floating upon it.
column3: As Eliza dipped her head under the water one of the toads sat on her hair, a second on her forehead, and a third on her breast, but she did not seem to notice them, and when she rose out of the water there were three red poppies floating upon it.

column2: Had not the creatures been venomous or been kissed by the witch they would have been changed into red roses.
column3: Had not the creatures been venomous or been kissed by the witch they would have been changed into red roses.

column2: At all events they became flowers, because they had rested on Eliza's head, and on her heart.
column3: At all events they became flowers, because they had rested on Eliza's head, and on her heart.

column2: She was too good and too innocent for witchcraft to have any power over her.
column3: She was too good and too innocent for witchcraft to have any power over her.

column2: When the wicked Queen saw this, she rubbed her face with walnut juice, so that she was quite brown; then she tangled her beautiful hair and smeared it with disgusting ointment, till it was quite impossible to recognize the beautiful Eliza.
column3: When the wicked Queen saw this, she rubbed her face with walnut juice, so that she was quite brown; then she tangled her beautiful hair and smeared it with disgusting ointment, till it was quite impossible to recognize the beautiful Eliza.

column2: When her father saw her, he was much shocked and declared she was not his daughter.
column3: When her father saw her, he was much shocked and declared she was not his daughter.

column2: No one but the watchdog and the swallows knew her, and they were only dumb animals and could say nothing.
column3: No one but the watchdog and the swallows knew her, and they were only dumb animals and could say nothing.

column2: Then poor Eliza wept, and thought of her eleven brothers who were all away.
column3: Then poor Eliza wept, and thought of her eleven brothers who were all away.

column2: Sorrowfully she stole away from the palace, and walked the whole day over fields and moors till she came to the great forest.
column3: Sorrowfully she stole away from the palace, and walked the whole day over fields and moors till she came to the great forest.

column2: She knew not in what direction to go; but she was so unhappy and longed so for her brothers who had been, like herself, driven out into the world, that she was determined to seek them.
column3: She knew not in what direction to go; but she was so unhappy and longed so for her brothers who had been, like herself, driven out into the world, that she was determined to seek them.

column2: She had been but a short time in the wood when night came on, and she quite lost the path; so she laid herself down on the soft moss, offered up her evening prayer, and leaned her head against the stump of a tree.
column3: She had been but a short time in the wood when night came on, and she quite lost the path; so she laid herself down on the soft moss, offered up her evening prayer, and leaned her head against the stump of a tree.

column2: All nature was still, and the soft, mild air fanned her forehead.
column3: All nature was still, and the soft, mild air fanned her forehead.

column2: The light of hundreds of glowworms shone amidst the grass and the moss, like green fire; and if she touched a twig with her hand ever so lightly, the brilliant fireflies fell down around her like shooting stars.
column3: The light of hundreds of glowworms shone amidst the grass and the moss, like green fire; and if she touched a twig with her hand ever so lightly, the brilliant fireflies fell down around her like shooting stars.

column2: All night long she dreamed of her brothers.
column3: All night long she dreamed of her brothers.

column2: She and they were children again playing together.
column3: She and they were children again playing together.

column2: She saw them writing with their diamond pencils on golden slates, while she looked at the beautiful picture book which had cost half a kingdom.
column3: She saw them writing with their diamond pencils on golden slates, while she looked at the beautiful picture book which had cost half a kingdom.

column2: They were not writing lines and letters, as they used to do, but descriptions of the noble deeds they had performed, and of all they had discovered and seen.
column3: They were not writing lines and letters, as they used to do, but descriptions of the noble deeds they had performed, and of all they had discovered and seen.

column2: In the picture book, too, everything was living.
column3: In the picture book, too, everything was living.

column2: The birds sang, and the people came out of the book and spoke to Eliza and her brothers; but, as the leaves turned over they darted back again to their places, that all might be in order.
column3: The birds sang, and the people came out of the book and spoke to Eliza and her brothers; but, as the leaves turned over they darted back again to their places, that all might be in order.

column2: When she awoke the sun was high in the heavens, yet she could scarcely see him, for the lofty trees spread their branches thickly over her head, and his beams were glancing through the leaves here and there like a golden mist.
column3: When she awoke the sun was high in the heavens, yet she could scarcely see him, for the lofty trees spread their branches thickly over her head, and his beams were glancing through the leaves here and there like a golden mist.

column2: There was a sweet fragrance from the fresh verdure, and the birds almost perched upon her shoulders.
column3: There was a sweet fragrance from the fresh verdure, and the birds almost perched upon her shoulders.

column2: She heard water rippling from a number of springs, all flowing into a lake with golden sands. Bushes grew thickly around the lake, and at one spot an opening had been made by a deer, through which Eliza went down to the water.
column3: She heard water rippling from a number of springs, all flowing into a lake with golden sands. Bushes grew thickly around the lake, and at one spot an opening had been made by a deer, through which Eliza went down to the water.

column2: The lake was so clear that, had not the wind rustled the branches of the trees and the bushes so that they moved, they would have appeared as if painted in the depths of the lake, for every leaf was reflected in the water, whether it stood in the shade or the sunshine.
column3: The lake was so clear that, had not the wind rustled the branches of the trees and the bushes so that they moved, they would have appeared as if painted in the depths of the lake, for every leaf was reflected in the water, whether it stood in the shade or the sunshine.

column2: As soon as Eliza saw her own face, she was quite terrified at finding it so brown and ugly; but when she wetted her little hand and rubbed her eyes and forehead the white skin gleamed forth once more; and, after she had undressed and dipped herself in the fresh water, a more beautiful king's daughter could not be found in the wide world.
column3: As soon as Eliza saw her own face, she was quite terrified at finding it so brown and ugly; but when she wetted her little hand and rubbed her eyes and forehead the white skin gleamed forth once more; and, after she had undressed and dipped herself in the fresh water, a more beautiful king's daughter could not be found in the wide world.

column2: As soon as she had dressed herself again, and braided her long hair, she went to the bubbling spring and drank some water out of the hollow of her hand.
column3: As soon as she had dressed herself again, and braided her long hair, she went to the bubbling spring and drank some water out of the hollow of her hand.

column2: Then she wandered far into the forest, not knowing whither she went.
column3: Then she wandered far into the forest, not knowing whither she went.

column2: She thought of her brothers, and felt sure that God would not forsake her.
column3: She thought of her brothers, and felt sure that God would not forsake her.

column2: It is God who makes the wild apples grow in the wood to satisfy the hungry, and He now led her to one of these trees, which was so loaded with fruit that the boughs bent beneath its weight.
column3: It is God who makes the wild apples grow in the wood to satisfy the hungry, and He now led her to one of these trees, which was so loaded with fruit that the boughs bent beneath its weight.

column2: Here she held her noonday repast, placed props under the boughs, and then went into the gloomiest depths of the forest.
column3: Here she held her noonday repast, placed props under the boughs, and then went into the gloomiest depths of the forest.

column2: It was so still that she could hear the sound of her own footsteps, as well as the rustling of every withered leaf which she crushed under her feet.
column3: It was so still that she could hear the sound of her own footsteps, as well as the rustling of every withered leaf which she crushed under her feet.

column2: Not a bird was to be seen, not a sunbeam could penetrate through the large dark boughs of the trees.
column3: Not a bird was to be seen, not a sunbeam could penetrate through the large dark boughs of the trees.

column2: The lofty trunks stood so close together that when she looked before her it seemed as if she were inclosed within trelliswork.
column3: The lofty trunks stood so close together that when she looked before her it seemed as if she were inclosed within trelliswork.

column2: Such solitude she had never known before.
column3: Such solitude she had never known before.

column2: The night was very dark.
column3: The night was very dark.

column2: Not a single glowworm glittered in the moss.
column3: Not a single glowworm glittered in the moss.

column2: Sorrowfully she laid herself down to sleep, and after a while it seemed to her as if the branches of the trees parted over her head, and that the mild eyes of angels looked down upon her from heaven.
column3: Sorrowfully she laid herself down to sleep, and after a while it seemed to her as if the branches of the trees parted over her head, and that the mild eyes of angels looked down upon her from heaven.

column2: When she awoke in the morning, she knew not whether she had dreamed this or if it had really been so.
column3: When she awoke in the morning, she knew not whether she had dreamed this or if it had really been so.

column2: Then she continued her wandering, but she had not gone many steps forward when she met an old woman with berries in her basket, and begged a few to eat.
column3: Then she continued her wandering, but she had not gone many steps forward when she met an old woman with berries in her basket, and begged a few to eat.

column2: Then Eliza asked her if she had seen eleven princes riding through the forest.
column3: Then Eliza asked her if she had seen eleven princes riding through the forest.

column2: No, replied the old woman, "but I saw yesterday eleven swans, with gold crowns on their heads, swimming on the river close by." Then she led Eliza a little distance farther to a sloping bank, at the foot of which wound a little stream.
column3: No, replied the old woman, "but I saw yesterday eleven swans, with gold crowns on their heads, swimming on the river close by." Then she led Eliza a little distance farther to a sloping bank, at the foot of which wound a little stream.

column2: The trees on its banks stretched their long leafy branches across the water toward each other, and where the growth prevented them from meeting naturally, the roots had torn themselves away from the ground, so that the branches might mingle their foliage as they hung over the stream.
column3: The trees on its banks stretched their long leafy branches across the water toward each other, and where the growth prevented them from meeting naturally, the roots had torn themselves away from the ground, so that the branches might mingle their foliage as they hung over the stream.

column2: Eliza bade the old woman farewell and walked by the flowing river till she reached the shore of the open sea.
column3: Eliza bade the old woman farewell and walked by the flowing river till she reached the shore of the open sea.

column2: And there before the young maiden's eyes lay the glorious ocean, but not a sail appeared on its surface; not even a boat could be seen.
column3: And there before the young maiden's eyes lay the glorious ocean, but not a sail appeared on its surface; not even a boat could be seen.

column2: How was she to go farther?
column3: How was she to go farther?

column2: She noticed how the countless pebbles on the seashore had been smoothed and rounded by the action of the water.
column3: She noticed how the countless pebbles on the seashore had been smoothed and rounded by the action of the water.

column2: Glass, iron, stones, everything that lay there mingled together, had taken its shape from the same power, and felt as smooth, or even smoother, than her own delicate hand.
column3: Glass, iron, stones, everything that lay there mingled together, had taken its shape from the same power, and felt as smooth, or even smoother, than her own delicate hand.

column2: The water rolls on without weariness, she said, "till all that is hard becomes smooth; so will I be unwearied in my task. Thanks for your lessons, bright rolling waves; my heart tells me you will lead me to my dear brothers." On the foam-covered seaweeds lay eleven white swan feathers, which she gathered up and placed together. Drops of water lay upon them; whether they were dewdrops or tears no one could say.
column3: The water rolls on without weariness, she said, "till all that is hard becomes smooth; so will I be unwearied in my task. Thanks for your lessons, bright rolling waves; my heart tells me you will lead me to my dear brothers." On the foam covered seaweeds lay eleven white swan feathers, which she gathered up and placed together. Drops of water lay upon them; whether they were dewdrops or tears no one could say.

column2: Lonely as it was on the seashore she did not observe it, for the ever-moving sea showed more changes in a few hours than the most varying lake could produce during a whole year.
column3: Lonely as it was on the seashore she did not observe it, for the ever moving sea showed more changes in a few hours than the most varying lake could produce during a whole year.

column2: If a black heavy cloud arose, it was as if the sea said, "I can look dark and angry too"; and then the wind blew, and the waves turned to white foam as they rolled. When the wind slept and the clouds glowed with the red sunlight, then the sea looked like a rose leaf.
column3: If a black heavy cloud arose, it was as if the sea said, "I can look dark and angry too"; and then the wind blew, and the waves turned to white foam as they rolled. When the wind slept and the clouds glowed with the red sunlight, then the sea looked like a rose leaf.

column2: But however quietly its white glassy surface rested, there was still a motion on the shore, as its waves rose and fell like the breast of a sleeping child.
column3: But however quietly its white glassy surface rested, there was still a motion on the shore, as its waves rose and fell like the breast of a sleeping child.

column2: When the sun was about to set, Eliza saw eleven white swans with golden crowns on their heads flying toward the land, one behind the other, like a long white ribbon. Then Eliza went down the slope from the shore and hid herself behind the bushes.
column3: When the sun was about to set, Eliza saw eleven white swans with golden crowns on their heads flying toward the land, one behind the other, like a long white ribbon. Then Eliza went down the slope from the shore and hid herself behind the bushes.

column2: The swans alighted quite close to her, and flapped their great white wings.
column3: The swans alighted quite close to her, and flapped their great white wings.

column2: As soon as the sun had disappeared under the water, the feathers of the swans fell off, and eleven beautiful princes, Eliza's brothers, stood near her.
column3: As soon as the sun had disappeared under the water, the feathers of the swans fell off, and eleven beautiful princes, Eliza's brothers, stood near her.

column2: She uttered a loud cry, for, although they were very much changed, she knew them immediately.
column3: She uttered a loud cry, for, although they were very much changed, she knew them immediately.

column2: She sprang into their arms and called them each by name.
column3: She sprang into their arms and called them each by name.

column2: Then, how happy the princes were at meeting their little sister again! for they recognized her, although she had grown so tall and beautiful.
column3: Then, how happy the princes were at meeting their little sister again! for they recognized her, although she had grown so tall and beautiful.

column2: They laughed and they wept, and very soon understood how wickedly their mother had acted to them all.
column3: They laughed and they wept, and very soon understood how wickedly their mother had acted to them all.

column2: We brothers, said the eldest, "fly about as wild swans so long as the sun is in the sky, but as soon as it sinks behind the hills, we recover our human shape.
column3: We brothers, said the eldest, "fly about as wild swans so long as the sun is in the sky, but as soon as it sinks behind the hills, we recover our human shape.

column2: Therefore must we always be near a resting place for our feet before sunset; for if we should be flying toward the clouds at the time we recovered our natural form as men, we should fall deep into the sea.
column3: Therefore must we always be near a resting place for our feet before sunset; for if we should be flying toward the clouds at the time we recovered our natural form as men, we should fall deep into the sea.

column2: We do not dwell here, but in a land just as fair, that lies beyond the ocean, which we have to cross for a long distance; there is no island in our passage upon which we could pass the night; nothing but a little rock rising out of the sea, upon which we can scarcely stand with safety, even closely crowded together.
column3: We do not dwell here, but in a land just as fair, that lies beyond the ocean, which we have to cross for a long distance; there is no island in our passage upon which we could pass the night; nothing but a little rock rising out of the sea, upon which we can scarcely stand with safety, even closely crowded together.

column2: If the sea is rough, the foam dashes over us, yet we thank God even for this rock; we have passed whole nights upon it, or we should never have reached our beloved fatherland, for our flight across the sea occupies two of the longest days in the year.
column3: If the sea is rough, the foam dashes over us, yet we thank God even for this rock; we have passed whole nights upon it, or we should never have reached our beloved fatherland, for our flight across the sea occupies two of the longest days in the year.

column2: We have permission to visit our home once in every year and to remain eleven days, during which we fly across the forest to look once more at the palace where our father dwells and where we were born, and at the church where our mother lies buried.
column3: We have permission to visit our home once in every year and to remain eleven days, during which we fly across the forest to look once more at the palace where our father dwells and where we were born, and at the church where our mother lies buried.

column2: Here it seems as if the very trees and bushes were related to us.
column3: Here it seems as if the very trees and bushes were related to us.

column2: The wild horses leap over the plains as we have seen them in our childhood.
column3: The wild horses leap over the plains as we have seen them in our childhood.

column2: The charcoal burners sing the old songs to which we have danced as children.
column3: The charcoal burners sing the old songs to which we have danced as children.

column2: This is our fatherland to which we are drawn by loving ties; and here we have found you, our dear little sister.
column3: This is our fatherland to which we are drawn by loving ties; and here we have found you, our dear little sister.

column2: Two days longer we can remain here, and then must we fly away to a beautiful land which is not our home; and how can we take you with us?
column3: Two days longer we can remain here, and then must we fly away to a beautiful land which is not our home; and how can we take you with us?

column2: We have neither ship nor boat."
column3: We have neither ship nor boat."

column2: How can I break this spell? said their sister.
column3: How can I break this spell? said their sister.

column2: And then she talked about it nearly the whole night, only slumbering for a few hours.
column3: And then she talked about it nearly the whole night, only slumbering for a few hours.

column2: Eliza was awakened by the rustling of the swans' wings as they soared above. Her brothers were again changed to swans, and they flew in circles wider and wider till they were far away; but one of them, the youngest swan, remained behind and laid his head in his sister's lap, while she stroked his wings, and they remained together the whole day.
column3: Eliza was awakened by the rustling of the swans' wings as they soared above. Her brothers were again changed to swans, and they flew in circles wider and wider till they were far away; but one of them, the youngest swan, remained behind and laid his head in his sister's lap, while she stroked his wings, and they remained together the whole day.

column2: Toward evening the rest came back, and as the sun went down they resumed their natural forms.
column3: Toward evening the rest came back, and as the sun went down they resumed their natural forms.

column2: To-morrow, said one, "we shall fly away, not to return again till a whole year has passed.
column3: To morrow, said one, "we shall fly away, not to return again till a whole year has passed.

column2: But we cannot leave you here.
column3: But we cannot leave you here.

column2: Have you courage to go with us?
column3: Have you courage to go with us?

column2: My arm is strong enough to carry you through the wood; and will not all our wings be strong enough to fly with you over the sea?"
column3: My arm is strong enough to carry you through the wood; and will not all our wings be strong enough to fly with you over the sea?"

column2: Yes, take me with you, said Eliza.
column3: Yes, take me with you, said Eliza.

column2: Then they spent the whole night in weaving a net with the pliant willow and rushes.
column3: Then they spent the whole night in weaving a net with the pliant willow and rushes.

column2: It was very large and strong.
column3: It was very large and strong.

column2: Eliza laid herself down on the net, and when the sun rose and her brothers again became wild swans, they took up the net with their beaks and flew up to the clouds with their dear sister, who still slept. The sunbeams fell on her face, therefore one of the swans soared over her head, so that his broad wing might shade her.
column3: Eliza laid herself down on the net, and when the sun rose and her brothers again became wild swans, they took up the net with their beaks and flew up to the clouds with their dear sister, who still slept. The sunbeams fell on her face, therefore one of the swans soared over her head, so that his broad wing might shade her.

column2: They were far from the land when Eliza woke.
column3: They were far from the land when Eliza woke.

column2: She thought she must still be dreaming, it seemed so strange to her to feel herself being carried so high in the air over the sea.
column3: She thought she must still be dreaming, it seemed so strange to her to feel herself being carried so high in the air over the sea.

column2: By her side lay a branch full of beautiful ripe berries and a bundle of sweet roots; the youngest of her brothers had gathered them for her, and placed them by her side.
column3: By her side lay a branch full of beautiful ripe berries and a bundle of sweet roots; the youngest of her brothers had gathered them for her, and placed them by her side.

column2: She smiled her thanks to him; she knew it was the same who had hovered over her to shade her with his wings.
column3: She smiled her thanks to him; she knew it was the same who had hovered over her to shade her with his wings.

column2: They were now so high that a large ship beneath them looked like a white sea gull skimming the waves.
column3: They were now so high that a large ship beneath them looked like a white sea gull skimming the waves.

column2: A great cloud floating behind them appeared like a vast mountain, and upon it Eliza saw her own shadow and those of the eleven swans, looking gigantic in size.
column3: A great cloud floating behind them appeared like a vast mountain, and upon it Eliza saw her own shadow and those of the eleven swans, looking gigantic in size.

column2: Altogether it formed a more beautiful picture than she had ever seen; but as the sun rose higher, and the clouds were left behind, the shadowy picture vanished away.
column3: Altogether it formed a more beautiful picture than she had ever seen; but as the sun rose higher, and the clouds were left behind, the shadowy picture vanished away.

column2: Onward the whole day they flew through the air like a winged arrow, yet more slowly than usual, for they had their sister to carry.
column3: Onward the whole day they flew through the air like a winged arrow, yet more slowly than usual, for they had their sister to carry.

column2: The weather seemed inclined to be stormy, and Eliza watched the sinking sun with great anxiety, for the little rock in the ocean was not yet in sight.
column3: The weather seemed inclined to be stormy, and Eliza watched the sinking sun with great anxiety, for the little rock in the ocean was not yet in sight.

column2: It appeared to her as if the swans were making great efforts with their wings.
column3: It appeared to her as if the swans were making great efforts with their wings.

column2: Alas! she was the cause of their not advancing more quickly.
column3: Alas! she was the cause of their not advancing more quickly.

column2: When the sun set they would change to men, fall into the sea, and be drowned.
column3: When the sun set they would change to men, fall into the sea, and be drowned.

column2: Then she offered a prayer from her inmost heart, but still no appearance of the rock.
column3: Then she offered a prayer from her inmost heart, but still no appearance of the rock.

column2: Dark clouds came nearer, the gusts of wind told of a coming storm, while from a thick, heavy mass of clouds the lightning burst forth flash after flash.
column3: Dark clouds came nearer, the gusts of wind told of a coming storm, while from a thick, heavy mass of clouds the lightning burst forth flash after flash.

column2: The sun had reached the edge of the sea, when the swans darted down so swiftly that Eliza's head trembled; she believed they were falling, but they again soared onward.
column3: The sun had reached the edge of the sea, when the swans darted down so swiftly that Eliza's head trembled; she believed they were falling, but they again soared onward.

column2: Presently she caught sight of the rock just below them, and by this time the sun was half hidden by the waves.
column3: Presently she caught sight of the rock just below them, and by this time the sun was half hidden by the waves.

column2: The rock did not appear larger than a seal's head thrust out of the water.
column3: The rock did not appear larger than a seal's head thrust out of the water.

column2: They sank so rapidly that at the moment their feet touched the rock the sun shone only like a star, and at last disappeared like the last spark in a piece of burned paper.
column3: They sank so rapidly that at the moment their feet touched the rock the sun shone only like a star, and at last disappeared like the last spark in a piece of burned paper.

column2: Then she saw her brothers standing closely around her with their arms linked together.
column3: Then she saw her brothers standing closely around her with their arms linked together.

column2: There was but just room enough for them, and not the smallest space to spare.
column3: There was but just room enough for them, and not the smallest space to spare.

column2: The sea dashed against the rock and covered them with spray.
column3: The sea dashed against the rock and covered them with spray.

column2: The heavens were lighted up with continual flashes, and peal after peal of thunder rolled.
column3: The heavens were lighted up with continual flashes, and peal after peal of thunder rolled.

column2: But the sister and brothers sat holding each other's hands and singing hymns, from which they gained hope and courage.
column3: But the sister and brothers sat holding each other's hands and singing hymns, from which they gained hope and courage.

column2: In the early dawn the air became calm and still, and at sunrise the swans flew away from the rock with Eliza.
column3: In the early dawn the air became calm and still, and at sunrise the swans flew away from the rock with Eliza.

column2: The sea was still rough, and from their high position in the air the white foam on the dark green waves looked like millions of swans swimming on the water.
column3: The sea was still rough, and from their high position in the air the white foam on the dark green waves looked like millions of swans swimming on the water.

column2: As the sun rose higher Eliza saw before her, floating in the air, a range of mountains with shining masses of ice on their summits.
column3: As the sun rose higher Eliza saw before her, floating in the air, a range of mountains with shining masses of ice on their summits.

column2: In the center rose a castle apparently a mile long, with rows of columns rising one above another, while around it palm trees waved and flowers bloomed as large as mill wheels.
column3: In the center rose a castle apparently a mile long, with rows of columns rising one above another, while around it palm trees waved and flowers bloomed as large as mill wheels.

column2: She asked if this was the land to which they were hastening.
column3: She asked if this was the land to which they were hastening.

column2: The swans shook their heads, for what she beheld were the beautiful ever-changing cloud palaces of the "Fata Morgana," into which no mortal can enter.
column3: The swans shook their heads, for what she beheld were the beautiful ever changing cloud palaces of the "Fata Morgana," into which no mortal can enter.

column2: Eliza was still gazing at the scene when mountains, forests, and castles melted away, and twenty stately churches rose in their stead, with high towers and pointed Gothic windows.
column3: Eliza was still gazing at the scene when mountains, forests, and castles melted away, and twenty stately churches rose in their stead, with high towers and pointed Gothic windows.

column2: Eliza even fancied she could hear the tones of the organ, but it was the music of the murmuring sea which she heard.
column3: Eliza even fancied she could hear the tones of the organ, but it was the music of the murmuring sea which she heard.

column2: As they drew nearer to the churches, these also changed into a fleet of ships, which seemed to be sailing beneath her; but as she looked again, she found it was only a sea mist gliding over the ocean.
column3: As they drew nearer to the churches, these also changed into a fleet of ships, which seemed to be sailing beneath her; but as she looked again, she found it was only a sea mist gliding over the ocean.

column2: So there continued to pass before her eyes a constant change of scene, till at last she saw the real land to which they were bound, with its blue mountains, its cedar forests, and its cities and palaces.
column3: So there continued to pass before her eyes a constant change of scene, till at last she saw the real land to which they were bound, with its blue mountains, its cedar forests, and its cities and palaces.

column2: Long before the sun went down she sat on a rock in front of a large cave, on the floor of which the overgrown yet delicate green creeping plants looked like an embroidered carpet.
column3: Long before the sun went down she sat on a rock in front of a large cave, on the floor of which the overgrown yet delicate green creeping plants looked like an embroidered carpet.

column2: Now we shall expect to hear what you dream of to-night, said the youngest brother, as he showed his sister her bedroom.
column3: Now we shall expect to hear what you dream of to night, said the youngest brother, as he showed his sister her bedroom.

column2: Heaven grant that I may dream how to save you! she replied.
column3: Heaven grant that I may dream how to save you! she replied.

column2: And this thought took such hold upon her mind that she prayed earnestly to God for help, and even in her sleep she continued to pray.
column3: And this thought took such hold upon her mind that she prayed earnestly to God for help, and even in her sleep she continued to pray.

column2: Then it appeared to her as if she were flying high in the air, toward the cloudy palace of the "Fata Morgana," and a fairy came out to meet her, radiant and beautiful in appearance, and yet very much like the old woman who had given her berries in the wood, and who had told her of the swans with golden crowns on their heads.
column3: Then it appeared to her as if she were flying high in the air, toward the cloudy palace of the "Fata Morgana," and a fairy came out to meet her, radiant and beautiful in appearance, and yet very much like the old woman who had given her berries in the wood, and who had told her of the swans with golden crowns on their heads.

column2: Your brothers can be released, said she, "if you have only courage and perseverance.
column3: Your brothers can be released, said she, "if you have only courage and perseverance.

column2: True, water is softer than your own delicate hands, and yet it polishes stones into shapes; it feels no pain as your fingers would feel, it has no soul, and cannot suffer such agony and torment as you will have to endure.
column3: True, water is softer than your own delicate hands, and yet it polishes stones into shapes; it feels no pain as your fingers would feel, it has no soul, and cannot suffer such agony and torment as you will have to endure.

column2: Do you see the stinging nettle which I hold in my hand?
column3: Do you see the stinging nettle which I hold in my hand?

column2: Quantities of the same sort grow around the cave in which you sleep, but none will be of any use to you unless they grow upon the graves in a churchyard.
column3: Quantities of the same sort grow around the cave in which you sleep, but none will be of any use to you unless they grow upon the graves in a churchyard.

column2: These you must gather even while they burn blisters on your hands.
column3: These you must gather even while they burn blisters on your hands.

column2: Break them to pieces with your hands and feet, and they will become flax, from which you must spin and weave eleven coats with long sleeves; if these are then thrown over the eleven swans the spell will be broken.
column3: Break them to pieces with your hands and feet, and they will become flax, from which you must spin and weave eleven coats with long sleeves; if these are then thrown over the eleven swans the spell will be broken.

column2: But remember, that from the moment you commence your task until it is finished, even should it occupy years of your life, you must not speak.
column3: But remember, that from the moment you commence your task until it is finished, even should it occupy years of your life, you must not speak.

column2: The first word you utter will pierce through the hearts of your brothers like a deadly dagger. Their lives hang upon your tongue.
column3: The first word you utter will pierce through the hearts of your brothers like a deadly dagger. Their lives hang upon your tongue.

column2: Remember all I have told you." And as she finished speaking, she touched her hand lightly with the nettle, and a pain as of burning fire awoke Eliza.
column3: Remember all I have told you." And as she finished speaking, she touched her hand lightly with the nettle, and a pain as of burning fire awoke Eliza.

column2: It was broad daylight, and close by where she had been sleeping lay a nettle like the one she had seen in her dream.
column3: It was broad daylight, and close by where she had been sleeping lay a nettle like the one she had seen in her dream.

column2: She fell on her knees and offered her thanks to God.
column3: She fell on her knees and offered her thanks to God.

column2: Then she went forth from the cave to begin her work with her delicate hands.
column3: Then she went forth from the cave to begin her work with her delicate hands.

column2: She groped in among the ugly nettles, which burned great blisters on her hands and arms, but she determined to bear it gladly if she could only release her dear brothers.
column3: She groped in among the ugly nettles, which burned great blisters on her hands and arms, but she determined to bear it gladly if she could only release her dear brothers.

column2: So she bruised the nettles with her bare feet and spun the flax.
column3: So she bruised the nettles with her bare feet and spun the flax.

column2: At sunset her brothers returned and were very much frightened when they found her dumb.
column3: At sunset her brothers returned and were very much frightened when they found her dumb.

column2: They believed it to be some new sorcery of their wicked stepmother.
column3: They believed it to be some new sorcery of their wicked stepmother.

column2: But when they saw her hands they understood what she was doing on their behalf, and the youngest brother wept, and where his tears fell the pain ceased and the burning blisters vanished.
column3: But when they saw her hands they understood what she was doing on their behalf, and the youngest brother wept, and where his tears fell the pain ceased and the burning blisters vanished.

column2: She kept at her work all night, for she could not rest till she had released her dear brothers.
column3: She kept at her work all night, for she could not rest till she had released her dear brothers.

column2: During the whole of the following day, while her brothers were absent, she sat in solitude, but never before had the time flown so quickly.
column3: During the whole of the following day, while her brothers were absent, she sat in solitude, but never before had the time flown so quickly.

column2: One coat was already finished and she had begun the second when she heard a huntsman's horn and was struck with fear.
column3: One coat was already finished and she had begun the second when she heard a huntsman's horn and was struck with fear.

column2: The sound came nearer and nearer; she heard the dogs barking, and fled with terror into the cave.
column3: The sound came nearer and nearer; she heard the dogs barking, and fled with terror into the cave.

column2: She hastily bound together the nettles she had gathered into a bundle and sat upon them.
column3: She hastily bound together the nettles she had gathered into a bundle and sat upon them.

column2: Immediately a great dog came bounding toward her out of the ravine, and then another and another; they barked loudly, ran back, and then came again.
column3: Immediately a great dog came bounding toward her out of the ravine, and then another and another; they barked loudly, ran back, and then came again.

column2: In a very few minutes all the huntsmen stood before the cave, and the handsomest of them was the King of the country.
column3: In a very few minutes all the huntsmen stood before the cave, and the handsomest of them was the King of the country.

column2: He advanced toward her, for he had never seen a more beautiful maiden.
column3: He advanced toward her, for he had never seen a more beautiful maiden.

column2: How did you come here, my sweet child? he asked.
column3: How did you come here, my sweet child? he asked.

column2: But Eliza shook her head.
column3: But Eliza shook her head.

column2: She dared not speak, at the cost of her brothers' lives.
column3: She dared not speak, at the cost of her brothers' lives.

column2: And she hid her hands under her apron, so that the King might not see how she must be suffering.
column3: And she hid her hands under her apron, so that the King might not see how she must be suffering.

column2: Come with me, he said; "here you cannot remain.
column3: Come with me, he said; "here you cannot remain.

column2: If you are as good as you are beautiful, I will dress you in silk and velvet, I will place a golden crown on your head, and you shall dwell and rule and make your home in my richest castle." And then he lifted her on his horse.
column3: If you are as good as you are beautiful, I will dress you in silk and velvet, I will place a golden crown on your head, and you shall dwell and rule and make your home in my richest castle." And then he lifted her on his horse.

column2: She wept and wrung her hands, but the King said: "I wish only your happiness.
column3: She wept and wrung her hands, but the King said: "I wish only your happiness.

column2: A time will come when you will thank me for this." And then he galloped away over the mountains, holding her before him on his horse, and the hunters followed behind them.
column3: A time will come when you will thank me for this." And then he galloped away over the mountains, holding her before him on his horse, and the hunters followed behind them.

column2: As the sun went down they approached a fair, royal city, with churches and cupolas.
column3: As the sun went down they approached a fair, royal city, with churches and cupolas.

column2: On arriving at the castle the King led her into marble halls where large fountains played, and where the walls and the ceilings were covered with rich paintings.
column3: On arriving at the castle the King led her into marble halls where large fountains played, and where the walls and the ceilings were covered with rich paintings.

column2: But she had no eyes for all these glorious sights; she could only mourn and weep.
column3: But she had no eyes for all these glorious sights; she could only mourn and weep.

column2: Patiently she allowed the women to array her in royal robes, to weave pearls in her hair, and draw soft gloves over her blistered fingers.
column3: Patiently she allowed the women to array her in royal robes, to weave pearls in her hair, and draw soft gloves over her blistered fingers.

column2: As she stood before them in all her rich dress, she looked so dazzlingly beautiful that the court bowed low in her presence. Then the King declared his intention of making her his bride, but the archbishop shook his head, and whispered that the fair young maiden was only a witch who had blinded the King's eyes and enchanted his heart. But the King would not listen to this; he ordered the music to sound, the daintiest dishes to be served, and the loveliest maidens to dance. Afterwards he led her through fragrant gardens and lofty halls, but not a smile appeared on her lips or sparkled in her eyes.
column3: As she stood before them in all her rich dress, she looked so dazzlingly beautiful that the court bowed low in her presence. Then the King declared his intention of making her his bride, but the archbishop shook his head, and whispered that the fair young maiden was only a witch who had blinded the King's eyes and enchanted his heart. But the King would not listen to this; he ordered the music to sound, the daintiest dishes to be served, and the loveliest maidens to dance. Afterwards he led her through fragrant gardens and lofty halls, but not a smile appeared on her lips or sparkled in her eyes.

column2: She looked the very picture of grief.
column3: She looked the very picture of grief.

column2: Then the King opened the door of a little chamber in which she was to sleep; it was adorned with rich green tapestry, and resembled the cave in which he had found her.
column3: Then the King opened the door of a little chamber in which she was to sleep; it was adorned with rich green tapestry, and resembled the cave in which he had found her.

column2: On the floor lay the bundle of flax which she had spun from the nettles, and under the ceiling hung the coat she had made.
column3: On the floor lay the bundle of flax which she had spun from the nettles, and under the ceiling hung the coat she had made.

column2: These things had been brought away from the cave as curiosities by one of the huntsmen.
column3: These things had been brought away from the cave as curiosities by one of the huntsmen.

column2: Here you can dream yourself back again in the old home in the cave, said the King; "here is the work with which you employed yourself.
column3: Here you can dream yourself back again in the old home in the cave, said the King; "here is the work with which you employed yourself.

column2: It will amuse you now in the midst of all this splendor to think of that time."
column3: It will amuse you now in the midst of all this splendor to think of that time."

column2: When Eliza saw all these things which lay so near her heart, a smile played around her mouth and the crimson blood rushed to her cheeks.
column3: When Eliza saw all these things which lay so near her heart, a smile played around her mouth and the crimson blood rushed to her cheeks.

column2: She thought of her brothers, and their release made her so joyful that she kissed the King's hand.
column3: She thought of her brothers, and their release made her so joyful that she kissed the King's hand.

column2: Then he pressed her to his heart.
column3: Then he pressed her to his heart.

column2: Very soon the joyous church bells announced the marriage feast, and that the beautiful dumb girl out of the wood was to be made Queen of the country.
column3: Very soon the joyous church bells announced the marriage feast, and that the beautiful dumb girl out of the wood was to be made Queen of the country.

column2: Then the archbishop whispered wicked words in the King's ear, but they did not sink into his heart.
column3: Then the archbishop whispered wicked words in the King's ear, but they did not sink into his heart.

column2: The marriage was still to take place, and the archbishop himself had to place the crown on the bride's head; in his wicked spite he pressed the narrow circlet so tightly on her forehead that it caused her pain.
column3: The marriage was still to take place, and the archbishop himself had to place the crown on the bride's head; in his wicked spite he pressed the narrow circlet so tightly on her forehead that it caused her pain.

column2: But a heavier weight encircled her heart--sorrow for her brothers.
column3: But a heavier weight encircled her heart-sorrow for her brothers.

column2: She felt not bodily pain.
column3: She felt not bodily pain.

column2: Her mouth was closed; a single word would cost her brothers their lives.
column3: Her mouth was closed; a single word would cost her brothers their lives.

column2: But she loved the kind, handsome King, who did everything to make her happy, more and more each day; she loved him with her whole heart, and her eyes beamed with the love she dared not speak.
column3: But she loved the kind, handsome King, who did everything to make her happy, more and more each day; she loved him with her whole heart, and her eyes beamed with the love she dared not speak.

column2: Oh, if she had only been able to confide in him and tell him of her grief!
column3: Oh, if she had only been able to confide in him and tell him of her grief!

column2: But dumb she must remain till her task was finished.
column3: But dumb she must remain till her task was finished.

column2: Therefore at night she crept away into her little chamber, which had been decked out to look like the cave, and quickly wove one coat after another.
column3: Therefore at night she crept away into her little chamber, which had been decked out to look like the cave, and quickly wove one coat after another.

column2: But when she began the seventh she found she had no more flax.
column3: But when she began the seventh she found she had no more flax.

column2: She knew that the nettles she wanted to use grew in the churchyard, and that she must pluck them herself.
column3: She knew that the nettles she wanted to use grew in the churchyard, and that she must pluck them herself.

column2: How should she get out there?
column3: How should she get out there?

column2: Oh, what is the pain in my fingers to the torment which my heart endures? said she.
column3: Oh, what is the pain in my fingers to the torment which my heart endures? said she.

column2: I must venture; I shall not be denied help from heaven. Then with a trembling heart, as if she were about to perform a wicked deed, she crept into the garden in the broad moonlight, and passed through the narrow walks and the deserted streets till she reached the churchyard.
column3: I must venture; I shall not be denied help from heaven. Then with a trembling heart, as if she were about to perform a wicked deed, she crept into the garden in the broad moonlight, and passed through the narrow walks and the deserted streets till she reached the churchyard.

column2: Then she saw on one of the broad tombstones a group of ghouls.
column3: Then she saw on one of the broad tombstones a group of ghouls.

column2: These hideous creatures took off their rags, as if they intended to bathe, and then, clawing open the grassy graves with their long skinny fingers, pulled out the bones and threw them about!
column3: These hideous creatures took off their rags, as if they intended to bathe, and then, clawing open the grassy graves with their long skinny fingers, pulled out the bones and threw them about!

column2: Eliza had to pass close by them, and they fixed their wicked glances upon her, but she prayed silently, gathered the burning nettles, and carried them home with her to the castle.
column3: Eliza had to pass close by them, and they fixed their wicked glances upon her, but she prayed silently, gathered the burning nettles, and carried them home with her to the castle.

column2: One person only had seen her, and that was the archbishop--he was awake while everybody was asleep.
column3: One person only had seen her, and that was the archbishop-he was awake while everybody was asleep.

column2: Now he thought his opinion was evidently correct.
column3: Now he thought his opinion was evidently correct.

column2: All was not right with the Queen.
column3: All was not right with the Queen.

column2: She was a witch, and had enchanted the King and all the people.
column3: She was a witch, and had enchanted the King and all the people.

column2: Secretly he told the King what he had seen and what he feared, and as the hard words came from his tongue, the carved images of the saints shook their heads as if they would say, "It is not so.
column3: Secretly he told the King what he had seen and what he feared, and as the hard words came from his tongue, the carved images of the saints shook their heads as if they would say, "It is not so.

column2: Eliza is innocent."
column3: Eliza is innocent."

column2: But the archbishop interpreted it in another way; he believed that they witnessed against her, and were shaking their heads at her wickedness. Two large tears rolled down the King's cheeks, and he went home with doubt in his heart, and at night pretended to sleep, but there came no real sleep to his eyes, for he saw Eliza get up every night and disappear in her own chamber.
column3: But the archbishop interpreted it in another way; he believed that they witnessed against her, and were shaking their heads at her wickedness. Two large tears rolled down the King's cheeks, and he went home with doubt in his heart, and at night pretended to sleep, but there came no real sleep to his eyes, for he saw Eliza get up every night and disappear in her own chamber.

column2: From day to day his brow became darker, and Eliza saw it and did not understand the reason, but it alarmed her and made her heart tremble for her brothers.
column3: From day to day his brow became darker, and Eliza saw it and did not understand the reason, but it alarmed her and made her heart tremble for her brothers.

column2: Her hot tears glittered like pearls on the regal velvet and diamonds, while all who saw her were wishing they could be queens.
column3: Her hot tears glittered like pearls on the regal velvet and diamonds, while all who saw her were wishing they could be queens.

column2: In the meantime she had almost finished her task; only one coat of mail was wanting, but she had no flax left, and not a single nettle.
column3: In the meantime she had almost finished her task; only one coat of mail was wanting, but she had no flax left, and not a single nettle.

column2: Once more only, and for the last time, must she venture to the churchyard and pluck a few handfuls.
column3: Once more only, and for the last time, must she venture to the churchyard and pluck a few handfuls.

column2: She thought with terror of the solitary walk, and of the horrible ghouls, but her will was firm, as well as her trust in Providence.
column3: She thought with terror of the solitary walk, and of the horrible ghouls, but her will was firm, as well as her trust in Providence.

column2: Eliza went, and the King and the archbishop followed her.
column3: Eliza went, and the King and the archbishop followed her.

column2: They saw her vanish through the wicket gate into the churchyard, and when they came nearer they saw the ghouls sitting on the tombstone as Eliza had seen them, and the King turned away his head, for he thought she was with them--she whose head had rested on his breast that very evening.
column3: They saw her vanish through the wicket gate into the churchyard, and when they came nearer they saw the ghouls sitting on the tombstone as Eliza had seen them, and the King turned away his head, for he thought she was with them-she whose head had rested on his breast that very evening.

column2: The people must condemn her, said he, and she was very quickly condemned by everyone to suffer death by fire.
column3: The people must condemn her, said he, and she was very quickly condemned by everyone to suffer death by fire.

column2: Away from the gorgeous regal halls was she led to a dark, dreary cell, where the wind whistled through the iron bars.
column3: Away from the gorgeous regal halls was she led to a dark, dreary cell, where the wind whistled through the iron bars.

column2: Instead of the velvet and silk dresses, they gave her the coats of mail which she had woven to cover her, and the bundle of nettles for a pillow; but nothing they could give her would have pleased her more.
column3: Instead of the velvet and silk dresses, they gave her the coats of mail which she had woven to cover her, and the bundle of nettles for a pillow; but nothing they could give her would have pleased her more.

column2: She continued her task with joy, and prayed for help, while the street boys sang jeering songs about her, and not a soul comforted her with a kind word. Toward evening she heard at the grating the flutter of a swan's wing; it was her youngest brother--he had found his sister, and she sobbed for joy, although she knew that very likely this would be the last night she would have to live.
column3: She continued her task with joy, and prayed for help, while the street boys sang jeering songs about her, and not a soul comforted her with a kind word. Toward evening she heard at the grating the flutter of a swan's wing; it was her youngest brother-he had found his sister, and she sobbed for joy, although she knew that very likely this would be the last night she would have to live.

column2: But still she could hope, for her task was almost finished and her brothers were come.
column3: But still she could hope, for her task was almost finished and her brothers were come.

column2: Then the archbishop arrived, to be with her during her last hours, as he had promised the King.
column3: Then the archbishop arrived, to be with her during her last hours, as he had promised the King.

column2: But she shook her head, and begged him, by looks and gestures, not to stay, for in this night she knew she must finish her task, otherwise all her pain and tears and sleepless nights would have been suffered in vain.
column3: But she shook her head, and begged him, by looks and gestures, not to stay, for in this night she knew she must finish her task, otherwise all her pain and tears and sleepless nights would have been suffered in vain.

column2: The archbishop withdrew, uttering bitter words against her; but poor Eliza knew that she was innocent, and diligently continued her work.
column3: The archbishop withdrew, uttering bitter words against her; but poor Eliza knew that she was innocent, and diligently continued her work.

column2: [Illustration: "ELIZA WENT, AND THE KING AND THE ARCHBISHOP FOLLOWED HER"]
column3: [Illustration: "ELIZA WENT, AND THE KING AND THE ARCHBISHOP FOLLOWED HER"]

column2: The little mice ran about the floor; they dragged the nettles to her feet, to help as well as they could, and the thrush sat outside the grating of the window and sang to her the whole night long, as sweetly as possible, to keep up her spirits.
column3: The little mice ran about the floor; they dragged the nettles to her feet, to help as well as they could, and the thrush sat outside the grating of the window and sang to her the whole night long, as sweetly as possible, to keep up her spirits.

column2: It was still twilight and at least an hour before sunrise when the eleven brothers stood at the castle gate and demanded to be brought before the King.
column3: It was still twilight and at least an hour before sunrise when the eleven brothers stood at the castle gate and demanded to be brought before the King.

column2: They were told it could not be, it was yet almost night, and as the King slept they dared not disturb him.
column3: They were told it could not be, it was yet almost night, and as the King slept they dared not disturb him.

column2: They threatened, they entreated.
column3: They threatened, they entreated.

column2: Then the guard appeared, and even the King himself, inquiring what all the noise meant.
column3: Then the guard appeared, and even the King himself, inquiring what all the noise meant.

column2: At this moment the sun rose.
column3: At this moment the sun rose.

column2: The eleven brothers were seen no more, but eleven wild swans flew away over the castle.
column3: The eleven brothers were seen no more, but eleven wild swans flew away over the castle.

column2: And now all the people came streaming forth from the gates of the city to see the witch burned.
column3: And now all the people came streaming forth from the gates of the city to see the witch burned.

column2: An old horse drew the cart on which she sat. They had dressed her in a garment of coarse sackcloth.
column3: An old horse drew the cart on which she sat They had dressed her in a garment of coarse sackcloth.

column2: Her lovely hair hung loose on her shoulders, her cheeks were deadly pale, her lips moved silently, while her fingers still worked at the green flax.
column3: Her lovely hair hung loose on her shoulders, her cheeks were deadly pale, her lips moved silently, while her fingers still worked at the green flax.

column2: Even on the way to death she would not give up her task.
column3: Even on the way to death she would not give up her task.

column2: The ten coats of mail lay at her feet, she was working hard at the eleventh, while the mob jeered her and said, "See the witch, how she mutters!
column3: The ten coats of mail lay at her feet, she was working hard at the eleventh, while the mob jeered her and said, "See the witch, how she mutters!

column2: She has no hymn book in her hand.
column3: She has no hymn book in her hand.

column2: She sits there with her ugly sorcery.
column3: She sits there with her ugly sorcery.

column2: Let us tear it in a thousand pieces."
column3: Let us tear it in a thousand pieces."

column2: And then they pressed toward her, and would have destroyed the coats of mail, but at the same moment eleven wild swans flew over her and alighted on the cart.
column3: And then they pressed toward her, and would have destroyed the coats of mail, but at the same moment eleven wild swans flew over her and alighted on the cart.

column2: Then they flapped their large wings and the crowd drew on one side in alarm.
column3: Then they flapped their large wings and the crowd drew on one side in alarm.

column2: It is a sign from heaven that she is innocent, whispered many of them, but they ventured not to say it aloud.
column3: It is a sign from heaven that she is innocent, whispered many of them, but they ventured not to say it aloud.

column2: As the executioner seized her by the hand to lift her out of the cart, she hastily threw the eleven coats of mail over the swans, and they immediately became eleven handsome princes; but the youngest had a swan's wing instead of an arm, for she had not been able to finish the last sleeve of the coat.
column3: As the executioner seized her by the hand to lift her out of the cart, she hastily threw the eleven coats of mail over the swans, and they immediately became eleven handsome princes; but the youngest had a swan's wing instead of an arm, for she had not been able to finish the last sleeve of the coat.

column2: Now I may speak! she exclaimed.
column3: Now I may speak! she exclaimed.

column2: I am innocent.
column3: I am innocent.

column2: Then the people, who saw what happened, bowed to her as before a saint, but she sank lifeless in her brother's arms, overcome with suspense, anguish, and pain.
column3: Then the people, who saw what happened, bowed to her as before a saint, but she sank lifeless in her brother's arms, overcome with suspense, anguish, and pain.

column2: Yes, she is innocent, said the eldest brother; and then he related all that had taken place, and while he spoke there rose in the air a fragrance as from millions of flowers.
column3: Yes, she is innocent, said the eldest brother; and then he related all that had taken place, and while he spoke there rose in the air a fragrance as from millions of flowers.

column2: Every piece of fagot in the pile had taken root, and thrown out branches, and appeared a thick hedge, large and high, covered with roses, while above all bloomed a white and shining blossom that glittered like a star.
column3: Every piece of fagot in the pile had taken root, and thrown out branches, and appeared a thick hedge, large and high, covered with roses, while above all bloomed a white and shining blossom that glittered like a star.

column2: This flower the King plucked and placed in Eliza's bosom, when she awoke from her swoon with peace and happiness in her heart.
column3: This flower the King plucked and placed in Eliza's bosom, when she awoke from her swoon with peace and happiness in her heart.

column2: And all the church bells rang of themselves and the birds came in great troops.
column3: And all the church bells rang of themselves and the birds came in great troops.

column2: And a marriage procession returned to the castle such as no king had ever before seen.
column3: And a marriage procession returned to the castle such as no king had ever before seen.
